summary: This is a letter from defense counsel Christian Everdell to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting a court order directing the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) to accept two hard drives containing discovery materials for Ghislaine Maxwell's review. The government does not object but requests the MDC be allowed to note objections.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; the letter is addressed to her requesting an order.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case; the request is to facilitate her review of discovery materials while detained at the MDC.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell; author of the letter requesting the court order.

connections.description: Everdell is defense counsel for Maxwell, as indicated by his request to facilitate her review of discovery materials.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Government Discovery Production
events.description: The government produced roughly 2.2 million pages of discovery in load file format.

events.title: MDC Objection Deadline
events.description: Deadline for the MDC Legal Department to submit any objections to the defense's request regarding the hard drives.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
Cohen & Gresser LLP, 800 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022
keyFacts: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell requested a court order to allow the MDC to accept two hard drives containing discovery materials for her review.
The discovery includes a November 18, 2020 production of approximately 2.2 million pages.
The hard drives are organized to be more user-friendly by grouping documents and eliminating duplicate file formats.
The U.S. Attorney's Office does not object to the defense's application but requested the MDC be allowed to note objections.
The document illustrates logistical challenges in managing voluminous discovery in a high-profile case while the defendant is in custody.
